title: The art of building legendary brands | Arielle Jackson (Google, Square, First Round Capital)
key_insights: A good name will help a startup, but a bad name won't kill a good company - focus on building great products and marketing over perfect naming
Positioning should come before any marketing work - if 10 customers describe your product differently, you have a positioning problem
Use the 'bar test' for positioning - you should be able to explain your product naturally in conversation at a bar
Brand personality needs tension to be interesting - define attributes as 'we are X but not Y' to avoid blandness
For PR, don't do straight funding announcements - use funding as a news hook to tell a larger story about product availability or customer momentum
Target the most specific audience possible initially - it's better to own a niche than try to be everything to everyone
The three pillars of brand development are Purpose (why you exist), Positioning (how customers understand your product), and Personality (how you show up)
Hire a marketer around 10 people when you have repeatable processes and multiple marketing problems that need ongoing attention

guest_background.current_role: Marketing Expert in Residence at First Round Capital

topics_discussed: Naming process and criteria for startups
The seven universal criteria for good names (trademark, domain, distinctiveness, timelessness, messaging alignment, pronunciation, appearance)
Brand development framework: Purpose, Positioning, Personality
Cultural tensions exercise for defining purpose
Jennifer Aker's five dimensions of brand personality
The bar test for validating positioning
Brainstorming techniques for naming (thematic and positioning-based)
When and how to hire marketing professionals
Working with over 100 startups as a consultant
Square Stand product launch case study
Visual brand identity vs. brand strategy
memorable_quotes: A good name is only going to help you, but a bad name won't hurt a good company... Disney means magic today. Volvo means safety. Those names are not good if I just put it in a spreadsheet, but they grew over time.
I'll never write a line of code without doing positioning first - that was music to my ears from a founder who took my class.
Your brand is who people think you are, and developing a brand strategy is what do you want to be and what are you going to do to help shape that perception.
frameworks_mentioned: Three P's of Brand Development (Purpose, Positioning, Personality)
Jennifer Aker's five dimensions of brand personality
The bar test for positioning validation
summary: Marketing expert Arielle Jackson shares comprehensive frameworks for startup branding, covering naming strategies, brand development (purpose, positioning, personality), and practical advice for early-stage marketing. The episode provides actionable processes and tools that founders can immediately apply to clarify their brand strategy and positioning.
